document_info.title: The Oilahuasca Theory: Complete Research Documentation
document_info.subtitle: Comprehensive Analysis of Allylbenzene Metabolism and CYP450 Enzyme Interactions
document_info.compiled_from: Conversation with Rev. Ryan Sasha-Shai Van Kush

executive_summary.definition: The Oilahuasca theory proposes that common culinary spices containing allylbenzenes can produce psychoactive effects when combined with strategic cytochrome P450 enzyme modulators - analogous to how ayahuasca uses MAO inhibitors to potentiate DMT.
key_findings: Allylbenzenes metabolize to tertiary aminopropiophenones (NOT amphetamines as originally theorized)
CYP450 enzyme manipulation can dramatically enhance bioavailability and duration
Multiple herbs create synergistic enzyme interactions
Scientific literature strongly supports core mechanisms
Significant safety concerns remain with this experimental system
executive_summary.analogy: Just as ayahuasca uses MAO inhibitors to activate DMT, oilahuasca uses CYP450 modulators to activate allylbenzenes from common spices

ron69.who: Pioneering researcher who coined the term 'Oilahuasca'
contributions: Systematically investigated pharmacological basis for psychoactive effects from culinary spices
Built upon Shulgin's theoretical framework with modern CYP450 research
methodology: Systematically studied NCBI, PubMed, WebMD databases
Identified CYP450 enzyme involvement in allylbenzene metabolism
Cross-referenced herbs that both contain allylbenzenes AND modulate CYP450
Developed activation theory analogous to ayahuasca's MAOI mechanism
ron69.key_insight: The same principle used in ayahuasca (enzyme inhibition to prevent drug breakdown) could be applied to culinary spices using CYP450 enzymes instead of MAO enzymes

credentials: PhD in biochemistry from UC Berkeley
Worked for Dow Chemical, then independent researcher
Synthesized and personally tested hundreds of psychoactive compounds
alexander_shulgin.ten_essential_oils_theory: Proposed that ten natural essential oils could theoretically be converted to psychoactive compounds through hepatic metabolism
alexander_shulgin.experimental_proof: Myristicin from nutmeg was shown to be converted to MMDA by passage through an in vitro liver preparation

ten_essential_amphetamines.note: While called 'amphetamines' by Shulgin, modern research shows actual metabolites are tertiary aminopropiophenones

critical_correction.historical_theory: Essential oils → Amphetamines through hepatic amination (Shulgin 1963)
critical_correction.why_it_matters: The metabolites are NOT amphetamines - they are structurally related but distinctly different compounds with potentially different pharmacological properties

step_3.name: Non-Enzymatic Condensation (Mannich Reaction)
step_3.note: This step is SPONTANEOUS - no enzyme required

type_1_dimethylamine.properties: Most polar, fastest renal clearance, shortest duration

type_3_pyrrolidine.properties: Least polar (most lipophilic), best BBB penetration, potentially longest duration

cyp450_identification.citation: Roles of human liver cytochrome P450 3A4 and 1A2 enzymes in the oxidation of myristicin

mechanism_based_inhibition.citation: Identification and characterization of reactive metabolites in myristicin-mediated mechanism-based inhibition of CYP1A2
findings: Myristicin most significantly inhibits CYP1A2 among five CYP enzymes tested
Glutathione blocks inhibition, proving reactive intermediate involvement

enzyme_induction.citation: Induction of rat hepatic cytochrome P450 enzymes by myristicin
enzyme_induction.finding: Myristicin causes 2-20 fold increases in liver P450 1A1/2, 2B1/2, and 2E1
enzyme_induction.dual_nature: Myristicin is BOTH acute inhibitor AND chronic inducer

gst_induction.citation: Preferential overexpression of a class MU glutathione S-transferase subunit in mouse liver by myristicin
gst_induction.finding: 4-14 fold increase in liver GST specific activity

mao_inhibition.citation: Evidence of Monoamine Oxidase Inhibition by Myristicin and Nutmeg (1963)
mao_inhibition.authors: Truitt, E.B., Duritz, G., Ebersberger, E.M.
mao_inhibition.finding: Nutmeg and myristicin show evidence of central MAO inhibition
evidence: Lower convulsive dose of intravenous tryptamine in mice
mao_inhibition.implication: Adds SECOND mechanism beyond CYP450 modulation

dose_response.medium_2-5g: Clear psychoactive effects, visual distortions, altered time perception
dose_response.high_5-10g: Strong hallucinations, significant altered consciousness, severe side effects

psychoactive_effects_confirmed.character: Dream-like, dissociative - NOT like classic psychedelics

the_paradox.question: Why would you both INDUCE (increase) and INHIBIT (block) the same enzyme?
the_paradox.naive_logic: More enzyme + Blocked enzyme = Cancel out?
the_paradox.actual_result: More enzyme + Blocked enzyme = MAXIMUM ACCUMULATION
the_paradox.analogy: Like building more highway lanes right before blocking them all - the bigger the highway, the worse the traffic jam when blocked

coffee_caffeine_cyp1a2_inducer.mechanism: Coffee compounds → Nuclear receptors (AhR, PXR) → Increased CYP1A2 gene transcription → 2-3x more enzyme

time_course.24-72_hours: Peak enzyme induction with regular consumption

coffee_caffeine_cyp1a2_inducer.why_induction_helps: More enzyme to inhibit = greater capacity for accumulation when blocked

nutmeg_myristicin_cyp1a2_inhibitor.mechanism: Mechanism-based (suicide) inhibition - enzyme processes myristicin, generates reactive intermediate that permanently destroys enzyme
nutmeg_myristicin_cyp1a2_inhibitor.recovery: Takes 24-72 hours to synthesize new enzyme

complete_strategy.step_1_preparation: Coffee drinking → CYP1A2 induction (24-48 hrs before)
complete_strategy.step_2_inhibitor_loading: Cinnamon, pepper, fennel → Block CYP3A4, 2C9, 2A6 + deplete glutathione
complete_strategy.step_3_substrate_loading: Nutmeg, parsley, dill, basil → Multiple allylbenzenes compete + myristicin inactivates CYP1A2
complete_strategy.result: Phase I minimal metabolism + Phase II blocked detoxification = Metabolite ACCUMULATION

coffee.role_in_oilahuasca: Preparation phase - increases enzyme capacity before blocking
coffee.dosing: 2-4 cups strong coffee, 30-60 min before or regular drinking 3-7 days prior

nutmeg.role_in_oilahuasca: Primary psychoactive source + primary enzyme inhibitor

cinnamon.role_in_oilahuasca: Blocks alternative metabolic pathways + prevents Phase II detoxification

black_pepper.role_in_oilahuasca: Blocks CYP3A4 backup pathway + enhances bioavailability

basil.role_in_oilahuasca: Triple action - allylbenzene source + SULT inhibition + palatable flavor
basil.dosing: 2-4 tablespoons fresh chopped or 1-2 teaspoons dried

fennel.role_in_oilahuasca: Dual action - provides estragole + blocks CYP3A4
fennel.note: Anethole is PROPENYL (not psychoactive pathway), estragole is ALLYL (psychoactive)
fennel.absinthe_connection: Was natural flavoring in original absinthe - may have contributed to 'altered state beyond alcohol'

parsley.role_in_oilahuasca: Source of highly potent apiole (→ DMMDA pathway)
parsley.note: Parsley SEED oil much more concentrated than leaves

dill.role_in_oilahuasca: Source of highly potent dillapiole (→ DMMDA-2 pathway)
dill.note: Dill SEED oil much more concentrated than weed/leaves

betel.caution: IARC Group I carcinogen with long-term use
betel.recommendation: Betel LEAF only (not areca nut), small amounts, not for chronic use

original_anecdotal_formula.claim: Some people have reported psychedelic effects from mixing just Coffee, Almond, Cinnamon, Vanilla and Nutmeg

components.nutmeg: Myristicin (primary psychoactive) + elemicin + safrole + CYP1A2 inhibition

original_anecdotal_formula.key_insight: Not just nutmeg's direct effects - an enzyme-mediated potentiation system analogous to ayahuasca

allylbenzene_vs_propenylbenzene.implication: Fennel's anethole (80-90%) is NOT psychoactive; only the 5-10% estragole contributes

acute_risks.nutmeg_toxicity: Severe nausea, vomiting, tachycardia, anxiety at 5-10g; convulsions possible at 10g+
acute_risks.duration_of_toxicity: Effects can last 24-72 hours or more

chronic_risks.hepatotoxicity: Safrole, estragole, methyleugenol may cause liver damage with chronic use
chronic_risks.carcinogenicity: Safrole restricted by FDA; betel is IARC Group I carcinogen

drug_interactions.cyp3a4_inhibition: Can increase levels of statins, blood pressure meds, immunosuppressants, benzodiazepines
drug_interactions.mao_inhibition: Risk of hypertensive crisis with tyramine-rich foods (though probably mild)
drug_interactions.warning: DO NOT combine with prescription medications metabolized by CYP450 enzymes

harm_reduction: Have comfortable setting planned for 24-72 hour duration
Do not drive or operate machinery

research_gaps: No controlled human studies on oilahuasca combinations
Exact potency of aminopropiophenone metabolites unknown
Individual variation in CYP450 activity not accounted for
Long-term safety of combination use unstudied
Receptor binding profiles of metabolites not characterized

connection_to_van_kush.shaivite_temple: The Shaivite Temple uses sacred plants including cannabis; this research extends understanding of plant-based consciousness exploration
connection_to_van_kush.75000_year_tradition: Knowledge of psychoactive plants has been preserved across temple cultures for millennia
connection_to_van_kush.book_of_tanit: This research may be included in the expanding Book of Tanit manuscript
connection_to_van_kush.educational_purpose: Document compiled for harm reduction and educational purposes, not encouragement of use
